title: In ‘Tulsa King,’ Sylvester Stallone Tries Something New: Being Himself
abstract: His best-known characters often speak in grunts. But in a new series from Taylor Sheridan, he plays a smooth talker written with his real personality in mind.

multimedia.caption: Sylvester Stallone plays a crime boss in “Tulsa King,” his first major TV role.
multimedia.copyright: Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Sylvester Stallone plays a crime boss in “Tulsa King,” his first major TV role.
multimedia.copyright: Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times

multimedia.copyright: Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times

title: This Land Is His Land
abstract: It’s too simplistic to label “Yellowstone” a “red-state drama.” But the cowboy soap speaks the language of culture war with a perfect accent.

title: An Artist’s Gateway to Freedom and Possibility
abstract: Torkwase Dyson distills stories of oppression and Black liberation into monumental artworks for her new show at Pace in New York.

multimedia.caption: Torkwase Dyson in her studio in Beacon, N.Y. Art can activate all of the senses, the sculptor and painter said. She made her largest works yet, a scramble of shapes and geometries, for her new show.
multimedia.copyright: Kendall Bessent for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Torkwase Dyson in her studio in Beacon, N.Y. Art can activate all of the senses, the sculptor and painter said. She made her largest works yet, a scramble of shapes and geometries, for her new show.
multimedia.copyright: Kendall Bessent for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Torkwase Dyson in her studio in Beacon, N.Y. Art can activate all of the senses, the sculptor and painter said. She made her largest works yet, a scramble of shapes and geometries, for her new show.
multimedia.copyright: Kendall Bessent for The New York Times

title: Paul G. Allen’s Art at Christie’s Tops $1.5 Billion, Cracking Records
abstract: A museum’s worth of masterworks from the Microsoft co-founder’s collection are offered in a two-part charity sale. Five topped $100 million.

multimedia.caption: Georges Seurat’s “Les Poseuses Ensemble (Petite version)” (1888) being auctioned during the Paul Allen sale at Christie’s in New York on Wednesday. The sale realized $1 billion with fees at about 8:30 p.m.
multimedia.copyright: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Georges Seurat’s “Les Poseuses Ensemble (Petite version)” (1888) being auctioned during the Paul Allen sale at Christie’s in New York on Wednesday. The sale realized $1 billion with fees at about 8:30 p.m.
multimedia.copyright: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Georges Seurat’s “Les Poseuses Ensemble (Petite version)” (1888) being auctioned during the Paul Allen sale at Christie’s in New York on Wednesday. The sale realized $1 billion with fees at about 8:30 p.m.
multimedia.copyright: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times

title: Steven Spielberg Gets Personal
abstract: In making his autobiographical film “The Fabelmans,” he confronted some painful family secrets, as well as what it means to be Jewish in America today.

multimedia.caption: After more than 50 years, this is the director’s most personal film yet.
multimedia.copyright: Chantal Anderson for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: After more than 50 years, this is the director’s most personal film yet.

title: ‘Black Panther: Wakanda Forever’ Review: Women on the Home Front
abstract: Shadowed by Chadwick Boseman’s death, this sequel focuses King T’Challa’s mother and the women helping her to contend with a slippery new villain.

multimedia.caption: In “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever,” T’Challa’s mother, Queen Ramonda (Angela Bassett), center, has assumed the throne.
In “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever,” T’Challa’s mother, Queen Ramonda (Angela Bassett), center, has assumed the throne.

title: ‘The Crown’ Review: The Worst of Times
abstract: The fifth season of the Netflix hit, with a new cast including Imelda Staunton as the queen, depicts the royal family at its lowest point.

multimedia.caption: Elizabeth Debicki plays Princess Diana in a Season 5 of “The Crown,” which is focused largely on Diana and Prince Charles.
Elizabeth Debicki plays Princess Diana in a Season 5 of “The Crown,” which is focused largely on Diana and Prince Charles.

title: In Search of Enheduanna, the Woman Who Was History’s First Named Author
abstract: “She Who Wrote,” an exhibition at the Morgan Library, explores the world of an ancient Mesopotamian priestess who wrote with a strikingly personal voice.

multimedia.caption: Two Mesopotamian sculptures from around 2112-2004 B.C., included in “She Who Wrote,” an exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum. The figure in the background holds a tablet in her lap, as if ready to write.
multimedia.copyright: Lila Barth for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Two Mesopotamian sculptures from around 2112-2004 B.C., included in “She Who Wrote,” an exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum. The figure in the background holds a tablet in her lap, as if ready to write.

title: How ‘Atlanta’ and ‘The Good Fight’ Chose Chaos
abstract: Two great but very different series, ending Thursday, decided that the most realistic portrait of America today is a surrealist one.

multimedia.caption: In the increasingly surreal world of “The Good Fight,” Diane Lockhart (Christine Baranski) therapeutically micro-doses psilocybin as the world falls apart.
In the increasingly surreal world of “The Good Fight,” Diane Lockhart (Christine Baranski) therapeutically micro-doses psilocybin as the world falls apart.

title: ‘The Fabelmans’ Review: Spielberg’s Own Sentimental Education
abstract: The director’s latest movie focuses on a budding filmmaker a lot like himself. But Michelle Williams, as his mother, is the soul of this fractious family drama.

multimedia.caption: The actor Gabriel LaBelle plays an adolescent Sammy Fabelman, a stand-in for Steven Spielberg.
multimedia.copyright: Merie Weismiller Wallace/Universal Pictures and Amblin Entertainment, via Associated Press

title: HarperCollins Workers Strike for Better Pay and Benefits
abstract: Employees say they’ll not return to work until they have a new contract. The company says it will “continue to negotiate in good faith.”
byline: By Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth A. Harris

multimedia.caption: Workers at HarperCollins staged a one-day strike in July. This time, they are striking indefinitely.
multimedia.copyright: Benjamin Norman for The New York Times

abstract: Plus: sculptural pepper mills, a fireplace-scented candle and more recommendations from T Magazine.

title: ‘Dancin’’ Revival to Boogie Onto Broadway in March
abstract: The show, originally created by Bob Fosse in the late 1970s, has been reimagined with the blessing of his daughter.

multimedia.caption: Ensemble members in “Bob Fosse’s Dancin’” during the show’s run at the Old Globe in San Diego this spring.

title: ‘My Father’s Dragon’ Review: Apocalypse Howl
abstract: A boy befriends a colorful creature in this animated film that struggles to maintain a consistent tone.

multimedia.caption: Elmer, voiced by Jacob Tremblay, with the dragon Boris (Gaten Matarazzo), in a scene from “My Father’s Dragon.”
Elmer, voiced by Jacob Tremblay, with the dragon Boris (Gaten Matarazzo), in a scene from “My Father’s Dragon.”

title: ‘Retrograde’ Review: The U.S. Withdrawal From Afghanistan
abstract: This documentary follows one Afghan general, Sami Sadat, to tell an emotional story.

multimedia.caption: In “Retrograde,” shot over the nine months after the confirmation of the U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan, the filmmakers single out scenes of vulnerability, fear and sheer nerves.
In “Retrograde,” shot over the nine months after the confirmation of the U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan, the filmmakers single out scenes of vulnerability, fear and sheer nerves.

title: ‘Falling for Christmas’ Review: Trip Down Memory Lane
abstract: Lindsay Lohan stars as an amnesiac who falls off a mountain and in love in this Netflix holiday romance that is all too familiar.

multimedia.caption: Lindsay Lohan and Chord Overstreet in “Falling for Christmas.”
Lindsay Lohan and Chord Overstreet in “Falling for Christmas.”

title: ‘Paradise City’ Review: John Travolta and Bruce Willis Reunite
abstract: Almost 30 years after “Pulp Fiction,” these kings of cool team up for a Hawaii-set action feature that isn’t as much fun as it sounds.

multimedia.caption: Bruce Willis in “Paradise City.”
Bruce Willis in “Paradise City.”
Bruce Willis in “Paradise City.”

title: ‘Sam & Kate’ Review: It’s a Family Affair
abstract: Darren Le Gallo’s drama stars two real-life parent-child duos — Dustin and Jake Hoffman, and Sissy Spacek and Schuyler Fisk — as lonely small-towners looking for love.

multimedia.caption: Jake Hoffman as Sam and Schuyler Fisk as Kate in “Sam & Kate.”
Jake Hoffman as Sam and Schuyler Fisk as Kate in “Sam & Kate.”
Jake Hoffman as Sam and Schuyler Fisk as Kate in “Sam & Kate.”

title: ‘The First Noelle’ Review: All I Want for Christmas Is My Ex
abstract: A young Black editor is set on winning back her ex-boyfriend this Christmas — even if it means breaking up his relationship.

multimedia.caption: In “The First Noelle,” Noelle (Novi Brown) tries to win back her ex, Terrance (Todd Anthony), after he returns home for Christmas with a new girlfriend.
In “The First Noelle,” Noelle (Novi Brown) tries to win back her ex, Terrance (Todd Anthony), after he returns home for Christmas with a new girlfriend.

title: ‘Nothing Lasts Forever’ Review: Mining the Diamond Myth
abstract: This documentary positions an intriguing investigation into the rise of synthetic diamonds within a broader excavation of the myths these stones carry.

multimedia.caption: Jason Kohn’s documentary dissects the diamond industry.
Jason Kohn’s documentary dissects the diamond industry.
Jason Kohn’s documentary dissects the diamond industry.

title: Mary Kelly’s Revolution Is Ongoing
abstract: The pioneering artist’s feminist work was groundbreaking in the ’70s. She never dreamed it would look just as radical half a century later.
byline: By Sophie Haigney and Philip Cheung

multimedia.caption: The artist Mary Kelly in her Los Angeles studio.
The artist Mary Kelly in her Los Angeles studio.
The artist Mary Kelly in her Los Angeles studio.

title: France Cheers for a Musical It Loves but Hasn’t Watched
abstract: Songs from “Starmania” are frequently heard and covered in France, but until a new production opened in Paris, few had a chance to see the 1979 rock opera onstage.

multimedia.caption: The ensemble in “Starmania,” directed by Thomas Jolly at La Seine Musicale.
The ensemble in “Starmania,” directed by Thomas Jolly at La Seine Musicale.
The ensemble in “Starmania,” directed by Thomas Jolly at La Seine Musicale.

title: Late Night Thinks Trump Is the Biggest Loser in the Midterms
abstract: The former president was said to be livid that candidates he endorsed lost on Tuesday, including Dr. Oz.
des_facet: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Trevor Noah (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

multimedia.caption: “On the bright side, Dr. Oz now can go back to doing what he does best, which is analyzing the shape and color of our stool,” Jimmy Kimmel joked.

title: Gal Costa, Singer Who Embodied Tropicália’s Innovative Spirit, Dies at 77
abstract: Her graceful, flexible voice and ear for memorable songs sustained a five-decade career defining the sound of Brazilian pop.

multimedia.caption: Gal Costa in 1996. Her recording career spanned more than 50 years and three dozen albums.
Gal Costa in 1996. Her recording career spanned more than 50 years and three dozen albums.
Gal Costa in 1996. Her recording career spanned more than 50 years and three dozen albums.

title: Warren Beatty Is Accused of Sexually Assaulting a Minor in 1973
abstract: In a lawsuit filed this week, the plaintiff says Mr. Beatty groomed and coerced her into sex when she was 14 and 15. The actor, who had starred in “Bonnie and Clyde,” was about 35 at the time.

multimedia.caption: The plaintiff says Warren Beatty caused her “severe emotional, physical and psychological distress.”
multimedia.copyright: Mark Von Holden/Invision, via Associated Press

multimedia.caption: The plaintiff says Warren Beatty caused her “severe emotional, physical and psychological distress.”

title: An Ancient People’s Oldest Message: Get Rid of Beard Lice.
abstract: Archaeologists in Israel unearthed a tiny ivory comb inscribed with the oldest known sentence written in an alphabet that evolved into one we use today.

multimedia.caption: A 3,700-year-old ivory comb found in southern Israel bears an inscription that reads, “May this tusk root out the lice of the hair and the beard.”
A 3,700-year-old ivory comb found in southern Israel bears an inscription that reads, “May this tusk root out the lice of the hair and the beard.”
A 3,700-year-old ivory comb found in southern Israel bears an inscription that reads, “May this tusk root out the lice of the hair and the beard.”

title: What’s in Our Queue? ‘The Watcher’ and More
abstract: I am a senior photo editor on The Times's Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching and listening to.

title: What to Do With the Time We Get
abstract: A man with a chronic illness savors the time he has with the ones he loves.

title: Joe Tarsia, an Architect of the Sound of Philadelphia, Dies at 88
abstract: His work as an engineer at Sigma Sound Studios left a sonic stamp on R&B hits by the O’Jays, the Delfonics, the Stylistics and many others.

multimedia.caption: Joe Tarsia, the founder of Sigma Sound Studios in Philadelphia and the engineer on scores of gold and platinum recordings, at the studio in 2003, the year he and his son sold it.
Joe Tarsia, the founder of Sigma Sound Studios in Philadelphia and the engineer on scores of gold and platinum recordings, at the studio in 2003, the year he and his son sold it.
Joe Tarsia, the founder of Sigma Sound Studios in Philadelphia and the engineer on scores of gold and platinum recordings, at the studio in 2003, the year he and his son sold it.

title: Elizabeth Stewart, Champion of Scotland’s Folk Music, Dies at 83
abstract: She was part of a musical family of Scottish Travellers that furthered the nation’s folk revival and influenced its American counterpart.

multimedia.caption: Elizabeth Stewart in 2003. She was, one folklorist said, “a peerless singer, pianist, storyteller, teacher, dealer and raconteur.”
multimedia.copyright: Alison McMorland, via University of Aberdeen

multimedia.caption: Elizabeth Stewart in 2003. She was, one folklorist said, “a peerless singer, pianist, storyteller, teacher, dealer and raconteur.”

title: Dispute Over Java Man Raises a Question: Who Owns Prehistory?
abstract: An Indonesian claim against a Dutch museum has pushed the debate about restitution into the realm of the natural history museum — where it hasn’t been much of an issue until now.

multimedia.caption: A skull cap belonging to Java Man, on display at the Naturalis Biodiversity Center in Leiden, the Netherlands. The ancient remains are believed to belong to Homo erectus, a “missing link” between humans and apes.
multimedia.copyright: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: A skull cap belonging to Java Man, on display at the Naturalis Biodiversity Center in Leiden, the Netherlands. The ancient remains are believed to belong to Homo erectus, a “missing link” between humans and apes.
multimedia.copyright: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times

title: How Peter Asher, a Jack-of-all-Trades in Music, Mastered Them All
abstract: The British musician, manager, producer, executive and author known for his work with Linda Ronstadt and James Taylor, is the subject of a new book exploring his unique run in the industry.
des_facet: Peter Asher: A Life in Music (Book)

multimedia.caption: From left: Gordon Waller and Peter Asher, of the duo Peter & Gordon. Asher’s long career in music is the subject of a new biography.
From left: Gordon Waller and Peter Asher, of the duo Peter & Gordon. Asher’s long career in music is the subject of a new biography.

title: A Walk Through the ‘Barbarian’ Basement With Zach Cregger
abstract: The writer and director of the twisty horror film “Barbarian” discusses its secrets while addressing some of the online chatter.

multimedia.caption: Georgina Campbell in “Barbarian.”
Georgina Campbell in “Barbarian.”

title: 50 Years of Stevie Wonder’s ‘Talking Book’
abstract: A conversation about the singer, songwriter and multi-instrumentalist’s studio innovations, and melding of social consciousness and musical creativity.
